solution.text:
Lets draw a square ABCD, then draw an equilateral triangle (\(\Delta ABP\)) on side AB as shown in figure,
Now, join A to C and draw an equilateral triangle (\(\Delta ACQ\)) on AC
Let, sides of the square be x units
i.e., AB = BC = CD = DA = x
Then,
AC = \(\sqrt 2\)x
Given that:
Area of \(\Delta ABP\) = 41 sq.units,
Since, \(\Delta ABP\) and \(\Delta ACQ\), both are equilateral triangle, thus they are similar triangles as we studied in previous exercises.
Therefore,
By Theorem 6.6, we have,
\(Area(\Delta ABP)\over Area(\Delta ACQ)\) = \(AB^2\over AC^2\)
i.e., \(41\over Area(\Delta ACQ)\) = \(x^2\over (\sqrt2x)^2\)
i.e., \(41\over Area(\Delta ACQ)\) = \(x^2\over 2x^2\)
i.e., \(41\over Area(\Delta ACQ)\) = \(1\over 2\)
i.e., \(Area(\Delta ACQ)\) = 82

content.text: If the area of an equilateral triangle described on one side of a square is 41 sq.units,then find the area of an equilateral triangle described on one of its diagonal .

solution.text:
\(\bigtriangleup \)ABC ~ \(\bigtriangleup \)PQR
\(\Rightarrow \frac {AB}{PQ}=\frac {BC}{QR}\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac {AB}{PQ}=\frac {2\times BD}{2\times QS}=\frac {BD}{QS}\)
Also \(\angle ABC=\angle PQR\)
Now in triangle,\(\bigtriangleup \)ABD and \(\bigtriangleup \)PQS
we have \(\angle ABD=\angle PQS\) , \(\frac {AB}{PQ}=\frac {BD}{QS}\)
\(\Rightarrow \bigtriangleup \)ABD ~ \(\bigtriangleup \)PQS
\(\Rightarrow \frac {AD}{PS}=\frac {AB}{PQ}\)
We know, \(\frac {ar(ABC)}{ar(PQR)}=\frac 1{400}=[\frac {AB}{PQ}]^2=[\frac {AD}{PS}]^2\)
Hence \(\frac {AD}{PS}=\frac 1{\sqrt 400}=\frac 1{20}\)

content.text:
Two triangles, \(\bigtriangleup \)ABC ~ \(\bigtriangleup \)PQR where QR=34cm.
It is given that lines from A and P intersect their opposite sides at D and S respectively such that BD=DC and QS=SR.
If the areas of the two triangles are in the ratio \(\frac {ar(ABC)}{ar(PQR)}=\frac 1{400}\)

solution.text:
given that st || qr
\(\Rightarrow \angle pst = \angle pqr\) and \(\angle pts= \angle prt\)(corresponding angles)
Now in \(\bigtriangleup \) pst and \(\bigtriangleup \)pqr , we have
\(\angle pst = \angle pqr\) and \(\angle pts= \angle prt\)
Therefore by AA criteria,\(\bigtriangleup \) pst ~ \(\bigtriangleup \)pqr
\(\Rightarrow \frac {area(pst)}{area(pqr)}= [\frac {pt}{pr}]^2\)
now we can see, area(pqr)=area(pst)+area(qrts)
it can also be written as area(pqr)=\(4\times \)area(pst) as \(3 \times \)area(pst)=area(qrts) [given]
\(\Rightarrow \frac {area(pst)}{area(pqr)}=\frac 14= [\frac {pt}{pr}]^2\)
taking square root on both sides we get\(\frac 1{\sqrt 4}=\frac {pt}{pr}=\frac 12\)
\(\Rightarrow pr=2\times pt\Rightarrow pt+tr=2\times pt\)
\(\Rightarrow pt=tr=2\)

content.text:
In the given figure st || qr and the area of quadrilateral (qrts) is three times area of \(\bigtriangleup \)pst.
If tr=2cm, find the length of pt.

solution.text:
Given that:
Area of \(\Delta ABC\) = 34 sq.units,
Area of \(\Delta PQR\) = 30 sq.units,
And AC = 11 units
By Theorem 6.6, we have,
\(Area(\Delta ABC)\over Area(\Delta PQR)\) = \(AC^2\over PR^2\)
i.e., \(34\over 30\) = \(11^2\over PR^2\)
i.e., \(PR^2 = {{121\times 30}\over 34}\)
i.e., \(PR^2 = 106.76\)
i.e., \(PR = \sqrt{106.76}\)
i.e., \(PR = {10.3}\)

content.text:
Areas of two similar triangle, \(\Delta ABC\) and \(\Delta PQR\) are given as 34 sq.units and 30 sq. units respectively.
If AC = 11 units, find PR.

solution.text:
It is given that \(\bigtriangleup \)ABC ~ \(\bigtriangleup \)PQR
\(\Rightarrow \frac {area(ABC)}{area(PQR)}= [\frac {AB}{PQ}]^2=[\frac {AC}{PR}]^2\)
given that area(ABC)=area(PQR)\(\Rightarrow \frac {area(ABC)}{area(PQR)}=1\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac {AB}{PQ}=\frac {AC}{PR}= \sqrt 1 \Rightarrow AB=PQ\,,\,AC=PR\)
Now in \(\bigtriangleup \)ABC and \(\bigtriangleup \)PQR, we have
\(\bigtriangleup \)ABC ~ \(\bigtriangleup \)PQR , AB=PQ and AC=PR
\(\Rightarrow \bigtriangleup ABC \cong \bigtriangleup PQR \)
As area of a triangle = \(\frac 12 \times base \times height\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac 12 \times BC \times AD=4\)
\(\Rightarrow AD=4\)
\(\Rightarrow PS=4\) as \(\bigtriangleup ABC \cong \bigtriangleup PQR \)

content.text:
Two triangles, \(\bigtriangleup \)ABC ~ \(\bigtriangleup \)PQR where BC=QR=2cm.
It is given that perpendicular from A and P intersect their opposite sides at D and S respectively.
If area(ABC)=area(PQR)=4, then choose the correct statements from the options given below.

solution.text:
Given that:
Area of \(\Delta ABO\) = 31 sq.units,
AO:OD = 1:2
i.e., \(AO\over OD\) = \(1\over 2\)
From the figure it can be seen that, \(\Delta ABO\) and \(\Delta DCO\) are similar triangles.
Therefore,
By Theorem 6.6, we have,
\(Area(\Delta ABO)\over Area(\Delta DCO)\) = \(AO^2\over DO^2\)
\(Area(\Delta ABO)\over Area(\Delta DCO)\) = \(({AO\over DO})^2\)
i.e., \(31\over Area(\Delta DCO)\) = \(({1\over 2})^2\)
i.e., \(31\over Area(\Delta DCO)\) = \(1\over 4\)
i.e., \(Area(\Delta DCO)\) = 124

content.text: In the given figure, if area of \(\Delta ABO\) is 31sq. units, and BC divides AD at O in 1:2 ratio.Find the area of \(\Delta DCO\)
